conclusion: To determine the temperature of the gas at state C, use the ideal gas law and properties of processes shown in the p-V diagram.
A to B is an isochoric process (constant volume); B to C is an isobaric process (constant pressure).
Given data: At state A: PA = 3 x 10^5 Pa, VA = 1 x 10^-3 m^3, TA = 27°C = 300 K. At state B: PB = 1 x 10^5 Pa, VB = 1 x 10^-3 m^3. At state C: PC = 1 x 10^5 Pa, VC = 3 x 10^-3 m^3.
The ideal gas law is given by PV = nRT.
Calculate temperature at state B using isochoric process: TB = TA x (PB/PA) = 300 K x (1 x 10^5 / 3 x 10^5) = 100 K.
Calculate temperature at state C using isobaric process: TC = TB x (VC/VB) = 100 K x (3 x 10^-3 / 1 x 10^-3) = 300 K.
The temperature of the gas at state C is 300 K or 27°C.
